CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A highly effective photovoltaic polymer with near - infrared response , poly{N- [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione-5 0 ,5 00 -diyl } {PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)} , was synthesized. The polymer has high molecular weight , good solubility , and a broad absorption spectrum in the range of 500-1100 nm. Field effect transistor charge mobility of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) arrived 0.05 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells based on PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PC 70 BM have broad photocurrent response wavelength range from 300 nm to 1.1 μm. High short - circuit current ( 14.87 mA / cm^2 ) and power conversion efficiency ( 2.71% ) were achieved , which is a significant advance for efficient photovoltaic polymers that respond to the whole range of the solar spectrum . In the past decade , polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have received a great deal of attention as a potential renewable energy source due to their potential advantages such as low fabrication cost , light weight , and fast production of large area devices by roll - to - roll solution processes. 1 Among photovoltaic polymers , regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT ) has been extensively studied. Bulk heterojunction ( BHJ ) photovoltaic device combining P3HT as the electron donor with [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester ( PCBM ) as the electron acceptor have achieved power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 4-5 % . 2 However , the upper limit seems to have been reached for this material combination , as P3HT utilizes only photons located in the highenergy fraction of the solar spectrum with wavelengths below 650 nm. In fact , ∼ 40% of the total solar energy lies in the range of 650-1100 nm , which is a strong driving force for developing lowbandgap polymers to utilize the solar energy in the near - infrared ( NIR ) range. 3 Recently , significant progress has been made in the photovoltaic application of novel low - bandgap polymers with optical absorption wavelengths in the range of 700-900 nm. 4 Nevertheless , design of efficient photovoltaic polymers with optical absorption and photocurrent response extending to wavelengths of micrometers remains challenging. The first example of this kind of micrometer - response polymer ( μmR - polymer ) was APFO - Green1 , reported by Ingan € as et al. in 2004.^5 Subsequently , considerable effort has been devoted to the design and synthesize of μmR - polymers via a synthetic strategy of combining electronrich units ( donors ) and electron - deficient units ( acceptors ) in a copolymer main chain. To date , no more than 10 μmR - polymers have been synthesized , which are primarily based on a very strong electron - deficient unit such as [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline , 6 thienopyrazine , 7 or thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole.

Let's think step by step.

1. Photovoltaic polymer, poly{N- [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione-5 0 ,5 00 -diyl } {PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)}
2. High molecular weight material
3. Good solubility
4. Bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells based on PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PC 70 BM
5. Regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT )
6. [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester ( PCBM )
7. Novel low - bandgap polymers
8. [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline
9. Thienopyrazine
10. Thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole

Note: The term "low-bandgap polymers" refers to a category of materials, and it is not possible to point to a specific material in the text. The same applies to "micrometer-response polymer (μmR-polymer)".
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. Photovoltaic polymer, PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)
2. Regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT )
3. [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester ( PCBM )
4. Novel low - bandgap polymers
5. [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline
6. Thienopyrazine
7. Thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| Photovoltaic polymer, PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) |
| Regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT ) |
| [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester ( PCBM ) |
| Novel low - bandgap polymers |
| [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline |
| Thienopyrazine |
| Thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole |

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A highly effective photovoltaic polymer with near - infrared response , poly{N- [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione-5 0 ,5 00 -diyl } {PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)} , was synthesized. The polymer has high molecular weight , good solubility , and a broad absorption spectrum in the range of 500-1100 nm. Field effect transistor charge mobility of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) arrived 0.05 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells based on PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PC 70 BM have broad photocurrent response wavelength range from 300 nm to 1.1 μm. High short - circuit current ( 14.87 mA / cm^2 ) and power conversion efficiency ( 2.71% ) were achieved , which is a significant advance for efficient photovoltaic polymers that respond to the whole range of the solar spectrum . In the past decade , polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have received a great deal of attention as a potential renewable energy source due to their potential advantages such as low fabrication cost , light weight , and fast production of large area devices by roll - to - roll solution processes. 1 Among photovoltaic polymers , regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT ) has been extensively studied. Bulk heterojunction ( BHJ ) photovoltaic device combining P3HT as the electron donor with [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester ( PCBM ) as the electron acceptor have achieved power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 4-5 % . 2 However , the upper limit seems to have been reached for this material combination , as P3HT utilizes only photons located in the highenergy fraction of the solar spectrum with wavelengths below 650 nm. In fact , ∼ 40% of the total solar energy lies in the range of 650-1100 nm , which is a strong driving force for developing lowbandgap polymers to utilize the solar energy in the near - infrared ( NIR ) range. 3 Recently , significant progress has been made in the photovoltaic application of novel low - bandgap polymers with optical absorption wavelengths in the range of 700-900 nm. 4 Nevertheless , design of efficient photovoltaic polymers with optical absorption and photocurrent response extending to wavelengths of micrometers remains challenging. The first example of this kind of micrometer - response polymer ( μmR - polymer ) was APFO - Green1 , reported by Ingan € as et al. in 2004.^5 Subsequently , considerable effort has been devoted to the design and synthesize of μmR - polymers via a synthetic strategy of combining electronrich units ( donors ) and electron - deficient units ( acceptors ) in a copolymer main chain. To date , no more than 10 μmR - polymers have been synthesized , which are primarily based on a very strong electron - deficient unit such as [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline , 6 thienopyrazine , 7 or thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole.

Let's think step by step.

1. High molecular weight - The paragraph mentions that the photovoltaic polymer PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) has high molecular weight, but it does not provide a specific numerical value for it.
2. Good solubility - There is no specific numerical value provided for the solubility of the polymer.
3. Broad absorption spectrum in the range of 500-1100 nm - This refers to the wavelength range over which the polymer can absorb light, and it is given as 500-1100 nm.
4. Field effect transistor charge mobility of 0.05 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 - This is a measure of how quickly the polymer can transfer charge, and it is given as 0.05 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1.
5. High short-circuit current of 14.87 mA/cm^2 - This is a measure of the maximum current that can be produced by the polymer when it is exposed to light, and it is given as 14.87 mA/cm^2.
6. Power conversion efficiency of 2.71% - This is a measure of the efficiency with which the polymer can convert light into electrical energy, and it is given as 2.71%.
7. Optical absorption wavelengths in the range of 700-900 nm - This refers to the wavelength range over which the novel low-bandgap polymers can absorb light, and it is given as 700-900 nm.
8. A very strong electron-deficient unit such as [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline, thienopyrazine, or thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole - These are examples of electron-deficient units that have been used in the synthesis of micrometer-response polymers, but no specific numerical values are provided for these units.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Broad absorption spectrum in the range of 500-1100 nm
2. Field effect transistor charge mobility of 0.05 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
3. High short-circuit current of 14.87 mA/cm^2
4. Power conversion efficiency of 2.71%
5. Optical absorption wavelengths in the range of 700-900 nm
6. A very strong electron-deficient unit such as [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline, thienopyrazine, or thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole

I have removed the irrelevant entities and kept only the entities that clearly refer to the values of material properties. These include the broad absorption spectrum of the PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) polymer, its field effect transistor charge mobility, high short-circuit current, and power conversion efficiency. I also included the optical absorption wavelengths of the novel low-bandgap polymers and the examples of electron-deficient units that have been used in the synthesis of micrometer-response polymers.
